author: lu_pinto
content:
I still feel that state creation incentives are a separate dimension to the disk reads and writes and also I'm kind of leaning on the same opinion from Andrew from erigon last ACDE that these state creation incentives look temporary and patchy since each one of the tracks in the future, either ZKvms or state expiry (or any solution to compress/archive state) would make these changes kind of irrelevant. I would prefer to fix this in an engineering way long term than in a solely economics way or a mix of both if required, but would certainly give priority to engineering first.
Having said that I think the simplest approach right now that allows us to scale is the best option, which is to track state incentives gas separately with a simple cap.
Maybe some old timers have more context, what happened to state compression/archival solutions?

author: sky.cactus
content: I am fully with you on fixing things for the long term, but I'm not aware of any concrete proposals that solve the long term state growth problem.  ZK definitely doesn't solve it.  State rent would, but I haven't seen that taken seriously for like a decade.  State expiry would potentially solve it, but last I checked that requires address space extension which was still a non starter.

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: The EF research team has been working on the topic of "state" quite extensively and both rent and expiry as well as client side improvements for significantly larger state are in the works. They will however only play out on the 3-5 year timeline imo

author: sky.cactus
content: Then we should increase the gas in 3-5 years.  Taking on debt because "we'll fix it in the future" doesn't pass the walk away test.
